text:
e="preserve">The Wildlife Protection Act of 1972 is a set of laws created in 1972 by the Government of India. Before 1972, India had only five national parks.
The Act protects wild animals, birds and plants in all of India, except the State of Jammu and Kashmir, which has its own wildlife act. It has six sections that give different degrees of protection. [http://envfor.nic.in/legis/wildlife/wildlife2s1.html Schedule I] and part II of [http://envfor.nic.in/legis/wildlife/wildlife2s2.html Schedule II] provide complete protection. Offences under these are given the highest penalty. Species listed in [http://envfor.nic.in/legis/wildlife/wildlife2s3.html Schedule III] and [http://envfor.nic.in/legis/wildlife/wildlife2s4.html Schedule IV] are also protected, but the penalties are much lower. [http://envfor.nic.in/legis/wildlife/wildlife2s5.html Schedule V] includes the animals that can be hunted. The plants in [http://envfor.nic.in/legis/wildlife/wildlife2s6.html Schedule VI] are prohibited from harvesting and planting.
